No one ever says the Democrat designed Atomic Bomb. It was designed by Americans with the assistance of allied scientists. I am an American of about ¼ German ancestry. ¼ Irish. 1/4 English. ¼ French.
Famous 1970s Documentaries like "World at War", narrated by Sir Lawrence Olivier, when I was younger used the terms American, British, French, Italian, German, or Japanese Armies. Allied Forces or Axis Forces were also commonly used. The use of the names Hitler and Nazi were used only when historically relevant.
Today, on the American Heroes Channel - AHC. ~20-30% of the mostly dicumentary type shows contain the word Hitler or Nazi in the brief "info" description of the show. To a person new to the subject it would appear that Hitler made every single decision in WWII. And that every, mostly conscripted, German soldier was a Nazi. This is untrue and propaganda to reinforce an agenda.
Less than 5% of the AHC shows are actually about American Heroes. That is unforgivable.

Buran was supposed to take off from an AN 255 aircraft. A fuel tank was attached to Buran and attached to the aircraft with it. Buran was supposed to take off with it the first few times, and then they would switch to the AN 255 option. AN 255 was recently destroyed in Ukraine

R-11 is not an ICBM as it is an SRBM while North Korea derived theirs from R-17 and later on enlarged and improved design along using UDMH instead of Kerosene.

Paektusan was first North Korean SLV while 2nd stage was SCUD-B derived, 3rd stage was solid fuel rocket.

North Korea forwarded to Iran design of Paektusan and Iran made modifications and improvements to it, hence Safir.

1st stage engine uses UDMH and N2O4 and 2nd stage is pair of verniers providing more output than verniers from R-27, later on using UDMH and N2O4 thus increasing thrust to 35.4 kN.

Iran successfully inserted few satellites with Safir rockets.

North Korea successfully inserted a couple of satellites with Unha-3 rocket.

Very cool video! Too bad that some things had to be left out for the sake of brevity. For example, the dreaded GRAU codes are in fact a very cool thing. Those are like US military "M1, M2 etc." naming convention, but made by sane people. While in US codes "M1" can refer to either a tank, a carbine, or a rifle, the GRAU codes provide a unique(!) designator to every model of equipment ever procured by soviet/russian army. What is more, the code structure allows you to know what you are looking at: for example, if the code starts with "6П..." it is a handgun, "6Ц..." is optical sights for handguns etc.
So, ballistic rockets were generally designated "15А...", and their engine subsystems were designated "15Д...", the "Д" standing for "двигатель" [dvigatel'] meaning "engine". Non-military rocket engines also had a military code (oh, Russia) of "17Д..."

ГРАУ, GRAU, is a General Artillery and Rocketry Office in Ministry of Defense.
And they have an inverntory type number for everything even remotely connected to shooting.
Starting with entrenching tool ending with intercontinental ballistic missiles and parts of those.
Each has a number like number letter number. Letter is a very coarse categorization, number and letter are category, number letter and number is particular type.
Like A is a artillery. 2A is canon. 2A46 is a 125 mm tank canon.

13:40 , a very tiny correction with the chemistry there. When you pass hydrogen peroxide over potassium permanganate, the peroxide breaks down into water and oxygen gas. This is a very exothermic reaction, so the water will very often boil if you have enough mass in one place reacting. So in turn, you have steam power, yes, but you also have large amounts of oxygen gas being produced mixing with that steam. This reaction is done quite often on a small scale and classrooms and in shows and is known as the elephants toothpaste experiment when soap is mixed with the peroxide. But yes, it seems like you only left out that it's not just steam being produced. You have a mixture of steam and pure oxygen being produced.

It can be added that the RD-170 is not a beast. This is just a little brother of the engine, which was supposed to become a real monster - RLA-1200 and set in motion a larger analogue of the Zenith rocket - RLA-150.
The RLA-1200 was supposed to have the same design as the RD-170, but the thrust was not 200 tons / chamber, but 300 tons / chamber.
The RLA-150 project was replaced by Energia. And the RLA-1200 was canceled.

Awesome video! One notice on N1. The KORD was not a flying computer, it was not controlling the engines. It was the system of emergency shutdown that should have turned off engines going out of the normal functioning. This system was required due to enormous number of engines on a rocket. Without the system a single engine failure would destroy the whole rocket. There were 2 problems with KORD though. 1: some engine failures were so rapid that could not be detected in time and the engine blasted off. 2: on the early versions of N1 it was sensitive to certain noise signals which caused false emergency shutdowns.

The first liquid fueled rocket engine was built and flown by Robert Goddard with National Geographic Society backing.  Goddard got his physics from the Russian Tsiolkovsky who of course relied on the English Newton's second law of motion.  Von Braun acknowledged that he used Goddard's designs as a starting point. Well done my friend. An incredible dissertation and history of the Soviet/Russian rocket engine programs.
Their solid engine program never really could scale up due to problems with formulating large batches of solid propellants. Their 1970's/1980s ICBM missile tests were rife with problems and RUD's.

They were finally able to succeed with the SS-13 SAVAGE ICBM that was deployed in the 1970's as a fixed site missile. It is speculated it was a almost direct copy of the American MINUTEMAN I ICBM.

The shelf-stable solid propellants were improved with the next series of ballistic missiles, culminating with the current SS-25 TOPOL mobile and fixed site ICBM series. It's ironic that there are no known rockets lofting payloads to orbit using solids propellants.

Another interesting point here. One of the main reasons why Russia was able to develop those high efficiency staged combustion cycles was because of the grade of kerosene they were able to get.

Heavy hydrocarbons are often hard to work with in engines because of a process called coking, where deposits of solid carbon (called coke or lacquer) form on the walls of your combustion chamber/regen cooling channels. This can be bad because you can have channels clogged with these deposits and it also lowers combustion efficiency.

Standard aviation fuels in the US (Jet-A or JP-8) are not coking resistant whereas fuels like JP-7 and RP-1 are because they’re more refined. One of the main bad actors in the generation of coke is it’s sulfur content. Sulfur acts as a catalyst for coking.

And it turns out, the oil mined in the Soviet Union contained naturally much less sulfur than the oil mines and refined in the US. This actually made it a lot easier for them to use kerosene as a coolant, and allowed them to work towards developing those engines when for the most part the US decided to focus on unlocking hydrogen as a fuel.

About John Glenn's first orbital flight in 1962. The United States Didn't send Alan Shepard or Gus Grissom into orbit, as they were unsure if the Mercury capsule could stand to fly that long. Slow and steady wins the race, as, though second to space, second to send up a woman, second to . . ., the United States was still, (and so far the only country), to place boots on the moon. If you lived through those early "Space Race" days, as I did, you followed along with each launch. The US followed the Soviets in every flight except for getting to th e moon first. The Soviets even landed a spacecraft on the moon before the US, the Luna series, which sent back photos of the moon, proving that it wasn't deeply covered in dust, as some American engineers thought at that time.

The fluorine engine is really interesting. If I was in charge of engineering the engine, I would add a gum coating to every surface that the fluorine would touch.
A light acid would wash through all of the plumbing to etch off the gum coating just before launch, followed by the hydrogen and then fluorine.
The same process I used to do to make photographic plates for a printing machine I used to work on.

Such mind boggling detail. It’s interesting that so many engine architectures were tried in the late 1950s and early 1960s. The Soviet Union was pushing on all fronts and the rivalry between design bureaus yielded a lot of positive, innovative and pragmatic solutions but it also had the negative effect of creating a lot of in-fighting and politics.   It was also wasteful and cripplingly expensive for an economy still recovering from the effects of WWII.  To thrust, weight, ISP and propellant composition it’s significant that Elon Musk added ‘thrust per dollar’ and, of all the metrics, today this is the most revealing.

Great Video, i love the effort and time put into making a comprehensive and easy to understand guide. But, i have one small correction at 47:07 the MR-UR-100 "Sotka" or "Spanker" was not the product of Vladimir Chelomei, it was Mikhail Yangel's 1970's replacement missile to replace the inaccurate and ageing UR-100 rockets with a new replacement that could fit in the existing silos.
Chelomei's replacement, the UR-100N aka "Stiletto" had to have the original silo's enlarged or new ones constructed as the new missile was much larger than the original design, though his design was more successful as it could carry a heavier payload and was more simple to service as it did not have the signature cold launch method that Yangel adopted from the 70's onwards.
Also these missiles were not to go against the R-36M, the Soviet leadership were pleased with the design and trusted Yangel with Heavy ICBM's.

Russia's upgraded Sarmat-2 ICBM launcher introduced features and capabilities that cost US $150 million dollars..........and made the expenditures on America's ABM missile defense system costing trillions of dollars over decades, obsolete.  Rockets are still very important to this day in shaping events and strategy.

Since this is a discussion of Soviet/Russian rocket engines, which were entirely designed in the metric system, why is the American engineering performance measurement ISp, specific impulse measured in seconds, used rather than the metric equivalent Veff, measured in metres per second.  The American measurement arises out of a confusion of using the same term, pound, for both the mass of the fuel and the thrust where the metric system uses kilograms for mass of fuel and newtons for thrust.

Missed out on many, many interesting tidbits which add historical context. Like that Glushko was a pioneer in rocket engines before the war, and how blown away they were at the first sight of the A4's engine, which they called "something that couldn't be" for having 10x more thrust they've ever been able to achieve at home. Or that the whole point behind R1 was to recreate A4 with indigenous materials: A4 used some 80 steel alloys, while USSR at the time had only ~30 to offer. It was mostly about metallurgy. Or that the Germans they brought back were not actually rocket scientists (Americans scooped all of those), just very good generic engineers and scientists who had to learn rocket science along with the Russians. And the sad part that the Germans, despite their good nature, honest work, and genuinely good ideas, were placed in a bubble on an island and never allowed access to real design work, their efforts mostly thrown in the garbage for the fears of sabotage or espionage.
